animalOfTheDay.name: wombat
facts: Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.

randomAnimals.name: oyster
facts: Oysters can change their gender multiple times during their lifetime.
A single oyster can filter up to 50 gallons of water per day.
Pearls form when an irritant gets inside an oyster's shell and is coated with nacre.
Oysters were so abundant in the 19th century that they were considered poor man's food.

randomAnimals.name: tamarin
facts: They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.

randomAnimals.name: harpy eagle
facts: Harpy eagles primarily hunt monkeys, sloths, and other tree-dwelling animals.
They are named after the harpies of Greek mythology, which were fierce winged creatures.
Its talons can be as long as a grizzly bear's claws, measuring up to 5 inches.
The harpy eagle is one of the largest and most powerful eagles in the world.
